content: Under the CRA, agencies must submit a report to Congress and the GAO before a rule can take effect, including a summary of the rule, designation of whether it is "major," and proposed effective date. Major rules require additional time for Congressional review, with GAO assessing the agency's compliance. Congress can use expedited procedures to overturn a rule by submitting a resolution of disapproval. The Congressional Review Act (CRA) allows Congress to use expedited procedures to overturn a rule by submitting a resolution of disapproval. The expedited procedures include a Senate committee being discharged from further consideration with a petition signed by 30 Senators, a nondebatable motion to proceed to consider the disapproval resolution requiring a simple majority, up to 10 hours of debate, and a simple majority vote for passage. If both houses pass the joint resolution, it is sent to the President for signature or veto. The Congressional Review Act (CRA) allows Congress to overturn a rule by submitting a resolution of disapproval. If the President vetoes the resolution, Congress can vote to override the veto. If a joint resolution of disapproval is signed by the President or Congress overrides the veto, the rule is deemed not to have had any effect. The CRA also prohibits the issuance of a rule in substantially the same form as the disapproved rule without specific authorization by a subsequent law. The Congressional Review Act (CRA) allows Congress to overturn a rule by submitting a resolution of disapproval. The CRA governs "rules" promulgated by a "federal agency," using the definition of "agency" provided in the APA. The more difficult interpretive issue is what types of agency actions should be considered "rules" under the CRA. The CRA adopts a broad definition of the word "rule" from the APA, but then creates three exceptions to that definition. The Congressional Review Act (CRA) allows Congress to overturn agency rules through a resolution of disapproval. The definition of "rule" under the CRA is broad, encompassing agency statements that implement, interpret, or prescribe law or policy. The CRA narrows this definition by excluding rules of particular applicability. The Congressional Review Act (CRA) allows Congress to overturn agency rules through a resolution of disapproval. The definition of "rule" under the CRA is broad, encompassing agency statements that implement, interpret, or prescribe law or policy. Determining whether agency action is a rule subject to the CRA involves a two-part inquiry: first, determining if it qualifies as a rule under the APA definition, and second, determining if it falls within any exceptions to the CRA's definition of rule. This section of the report provides a detailed explanation of these two elements. Courts have distinguished agency rulemaking actions from adjudicatory and investigatory functions. To qualify as a rule under the APA, an agency statement must be of general applicability, have future effect, and be designed to implement, interpret, or prescribe law or policy. The CRA exempts rules of particular applicability, rules relating to agency management or personnel, and any rule of agency organization, procedure, or practice that does not substantially affect non-agency parties' rights or obligations. Both inquiries are fact-specific. The CRA defines the word "rule" by incorporating the APA's definition. Courts determine if an action is a rule or order based on its substance, not just its label. Adjudications resolve specific disputes, while rulemaking affects broad classes of individuals. Rulemaking is prospective and has a definitive effect on individuals after the rule is applied. Courts distinguish rules from agency investigations, with some investigative actions not subject to rulemaking requirements. However, some actions related to investigations may qualify as rules, as observed in a federal court of appeals case. The legal effect test for notice-and-comment rulemaking determines if a rule binds an agency, while the future effect inquiry tests if an agency action is considered a "rule" under the APA. These tests are tied to different statutory provisions and should not both rely on whether a rule is legally binding. This is especially relevant for interpretive rules that may not require notice-and-comment but are still considered "rules" within the APA. The APA defines interpretive rules as "rules" exempt from notice-and-comment procedures. Agency actions must implement, interpret, or prescribe law or policy to be considered APA rules. Notice-and-comment rulemaking requires agencies to publish proposed rules in the Federal Register and allow public comment. However, certain agency acts like interpretative rules, general policy statements, or organizational rules are exempt from these procedures. The APA's rulemaking procedures do not apply to agency management or personnel matters. The CRA mandates agencies to submit rules to Congress and GAO before they take effect, including those from APA procedures and other agency statements. The CRA mandates agencies to submit reports to Congress and the Comptroller General, including a general statement, proposed effective date, and cost-benefit analysis for rules. GAO assesses compliance with additional informational requirements for major rules and includes its assessment in the major rule report. The report must be submitted to House and Senate committees within 15 calendar days. The report agencies must submit to Congress and the Comptroller General, along with the rule, is a two-page form containing required information. OMB provided a standard form for agencies to use in FY1999, as part of guidance on CRA compliance. Notice of final rule submission to Congress is included in daily Congressional sections. Submission of rules to Congress under the CRA is crucial as it triggers expedited procedures for introducing and considering a resolution of disapproval. This allows Members to use special "fast track" procedures to consider resolutions if agencies fail to submit rules to Congress. After the enactment of the CRA in 1996, concerns were raised about agencies not submitting their rules as required. The Emergency Sale Timber Program was established to increase salvage timber sales for forest health. A memorandum from the Secretary of Agriculture regarding the program was deemed a rule under the CRA by GAO. The Department of Agriculture's Forest Service issued the Tongass National Forest Land and Resource Management Plan, which sets management direction for the forest. GAO concluded that the plan was a rule under the CRA and not excepted under 5 U.S.C. §804(3). President Clinton signed Executive Order 13061 related to the American Heritage River Initiative. The American Heritage River Initiative (AHRI) aimed to support communities in restoring and protecting rivers. President Clinton's Executive Order 13061 designated 10 rivers for the program. The Government Accountability Office (GAO) determined that actions by the President are not subject to the Congressional Review Act (CRA). The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) issued guidance on investigating Title VI complaints challenging permits, which GAO deemed as affecting non-agency parties and therefore a rule under the CRA. The Farm Credit Administration issued a booklet providing guidance on national charters, which GAO determined to be a legislative rule under the CRA, requiring informal rulemaking procedures. The GAO concluded that the Trinity River Record of Decision (ROD) was a "rule" under the CRA due to its policy-setting nature and broad effects on non-agency parties. The ROD outlined actions to restore anadromous fish in the Trinity River by addressing decreased river flows in the basin. The Department of Veterans Affairs issued a memorandum directing network directors to stop certain activities aimed at enrolling new veterans in the VA health care system. The Government Accountability Office (GAO) determined that the memorandum was not a rule under the Congressional Review Act (CRA) as it was considered a statement of agency procedure or practice that did not affect the rights or obligations of non-agency parties. The VA issued a memorandum terminating the Vendee Loan Program, which allowed the VA to make loans for the sale of foreclosed VA-guaranteed property. The memorandum, addressed to directors and loan guarantee officers, announced the discontinuation of financing for the sale of acquired properties. GAO concluded it was not a rule under the CRA as it related to agency management and did not substantially affect non-agency parties' rights or obligations. The VA terminated the Vendee Loan Program, a discretionary management decision that did not affect any party's rights or obligations. The Government Accountability Office (GAO) determined that a letter regarding the State Children's Health Insurance Program and an information memorandum about the Temporary Assistance for Needy Families program were rules under the Congressional Review Act (CRA). The letter clarified requirements for the SCHIP program, while the memorandum offered waivers for TANF work requirements. The GAO determined that a memorandum regarding the Temporary Assistance for Needy Families program was a rule under the Congressional Review Act. It established criteria for states to apply for waivers from TANF requirements. On January 8, 2014, the EPA issued a proposed rule for greenhouse gas emissions from new stationary sources. The GAO concluded that the proposed rule regarding steam generating units and natural gas-fired combustion turbines was not covered by the CRA, as it only applies to final rules. Additionally, the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency issued interagency guidance on leveraged lending on March 22, 2013. The GAO concluded that the leveraged-lending guidance was a rule under the CRA due to its future effect and lack of exceptions. The guidance included principles for safe-and-sound leveraged lending activities for agency-supervised institutions. The Forest Service amended the Tongass Land and Resource Management Plan, which outlines forest uses in different areas. The amendment was deemed a substantive rule under the CRA by the GAO, impacting the regulated community. The Bureau of Land Management also issued resource management plans for four areas in Alaska. The GAO concluded that the Eastern Interior Plan was a rule under the CRA due to its general applicability and future effect in implementing law or policy. The plan designated uses by nonagency parties in specific areas and did not fall under the exceptions. On March 21, 2013, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau issued guidance on indirect auto lenders' compliance with the Equal Credit Opportunity Act. The GAO concluded that the bulletin on indirect auto lenders' compliance with fair lending requirements was a rule under the CRA. President Trump released a memorandum on global health assistance funding. The City Policy prohibited assistance to foreign organizations promoting abortion. The Department of State and USAID issued fact sheets to implement the policy. GAO determined these actions were not rules under the CRA as they were implementing the President's decision. The court ruled that agency actions implementing President Trump's policy decision were not subject to review under the APA, citing precedent that the President has broad discretion in foreign affairs. IRS announced it would not accept electronically filed tax returns without ACA reporting requirements for the 2018 tax filing season. The Government Accountability Office (GAO) concluded that the agency statement regarding full-year health coverage and shared responsibility payments is not a rule under the CRA. The Social Security Administration's (SSA) manual outlines how disability benefit claims are processed under the Social Security Act. The SSA manual policy prohibits using Internet information in benefit claim decisions, except for specific procedures. GAO determined these sections are procedural rules exempt from the CRA. IRS issued Revenue Procedure 2018-38 modifying reporting requirements for tax-exempt entities, submitted to Congress under the CRA. Senator Orrin Hatch requested GAO's opinion on the matter. The GAO was asked by Senator Orrin Hatch to determine if the IRS revenue procedure submitted under the CRA was considered a "rule." The IRS argued it was not covered by the CRA, but submitted it for Congress to decide. This was a unique situation as the GAO had to consider the CRA's application after the IRS had already submitted the procedure to Congress. The GAO confirmed that the IRS revenue procedure was available for congressional review under the CRA because the IRS had already submitted it, triggering Congress's oversight powers. GAO's opinion focused on the submission triggering review, stating that there was no impediment to Congress exercising its powers under the CRA. The GAO concluded that the April 2018 memorandum on zero-tolerance for illegal border crossings was not a rule under the CRA as it pertained to agency organization and did not change individuals' rights. This exception was covered by 5 U.S.C. §804(3)(C). In 2018, the Secretary of Commerce justified adding a citizenship question to the 2020 census in a memorandum to the Under Secretary of Commerce for Economic Affairs. The Census Bureau included the citizenship question in its planned questions for the census after receiving the directive from the Secretary. The GAO determined that the memorandum was not a rule under the CRA, as it was part of the statutory process of informing Congress about census questions. The memorandum justifying the citizenship question on the census did not meet the definition of a "rule" under the CRA, as it was part of the process of informing Congress about census questions.
